title: Bafta TV Awards introduce new rule ensuring diversity requirements are met
text:
Bafta has introduced diversity guidelines (Picture: Wenn)

Bafta has made changes to their yearly TV Awards to make sure that the shows nominated are as diverse as possible.

The organisation confirmed that programmes will now have to hit targets, in line with the BFI Diversity Standards, in order to qualify for entry and aims to have this new rule fully rolled out for 2021.

Amanda Berry OBE, CEO at Bafta , said: ‘Working in close consultation with the BFI and the wider television industry, we are delighted to be piloting the introduction of the BFI Diversity Standards, with the plan to fully introduce diversity standards for 2021.

‘Our aim is to bring the industry together to improve diversity and inclusion through sharing best practice, encouraging collaboration, driving change and, ultimately, to become more inclusive.’

On top of that, Bafta revealed it has updated its eligibility rules for the 2020 ceremony following this year’s Killing Eve controversy.

The hit series received three accolades at the awards earlier this year including Best Drama, despite guidelines stipulating that a programme must have premiered in the UK.

Killing Eve picked up three awards this year (Picture: Rex)

From now on, UK programmes will no longer have to premiere in the UK to be eligible for UK production categories.

Programmes that first transmitted abroad will be able to qualify but must be broadcast to UK audiences within the calendar year and programmes will be eligible for UK categories if they are initiated and developed in the UK and have creative control residing within the UK and/or a UK broadcaster has primary control.

This year’s Bafta TV Awards kicked took place in May and saw Killing Eve take home three gongs.

Fiona Shaw was awarded Best Supporting Actress for her role as Carolyn, while Jodie Comer was crowned Best Leading Actress for her portrayal of Villanelle and the programme itself won Best Drama Series.

Elsewhere, other winners included Benedict Cumberbatch for Best Leading Actor, I’m A Celebrity… Get Me Out Of Here! for Best Reality & Constructed Reality and EastEnders for Best Soap & Continued Drama.
